title: 1950s B-Movie Font
content:
Apologies if this is a stupid question or if it has been asked before (I'm a complete novice), but I am attempting to replicate the font(s) attached. Can anyone recognise it/them? The sample below is from "The Beast From 20 000 Fathoms" trailer. Any help is much appreciated. I can provide more samples if necessary.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043628im_/http:/typophile.com/files/50s%20font_5691.jpg)
author: fiftiesfan

comments.content:
Hello R.K.,

this was most likely hand-lettered.  
 [Bello Small Caps](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043628/http:/www.underware.nl/site2/index.php?id1=bello&id2=smallcaps) could work as an approximation.

Some more links to check out:  
 [House Industries](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043628/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=fontsbystyle&s=13)  
 [Movie Poster Type](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043628/http:/typophile.com/node/36650)  
 [Brush scripts c 1940s movie posters](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043628/http:/www.typophile.com/node/31976)  
F

I love lettering like this & I'm trying to perfect the style myself. If you ever get hold of old sign painting books you'll find alphabets like this usually called "Casual" or sometimes "Utility". Red Rooster's [Portobello](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043628/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/portobello-rr/) is another close-ish one, especially the demi, bold & extra bold weights.

I've just noticed Bello & Portobello. I presume there is a connection but what is the source?

Thanks, guys. I might try to get my hands on some of those old sign writing books!  
Ryan.
